newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 8.
newsitem.headline: INDIAN HEADLINE STOCKS - factors to watch - May 8.

text.p: Following are some of the main factors affecting Indian stock markets on Thursday morning:
Indian Finance Minister P. Chidambaram on Wednesday brushed aside demands by left-wing allies and political rivals, and stood by his landmark 1997/98 (April-March) budget.
"No major changes have been made in taxation and on customs duties," Chidambaram told parliament as he moved the budget plan that would slash corporate and personal income taxes.

Leaders of the left-wing parties, the Congress party and the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) met Chidambaram earlier this week and pressed for changes in the tax and tariff plan, which he first presented to parliament on February 28.
The four left-wing parties in Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral's 15-party United Front coalition had objected to the tax cuts as well as a proposal to open up insurance to private competition.

India's export growth fell sharply in 1996/97 (April-March) and industrial growth stumbled in the first 10 months of the fiscal year, reflecting a worrisome slowdown in the economy, analysts said on Wednesday.

"The trade gap is alarming and growth in exports has been has been discouraging," said a spokesman for the Federation of Indian Exporters Organisation (FIEO). "We were expecting exports to grow at eight to nine percent."

Exports grew at 4.01 percent to $33.11 billion in 1996/97 compared with 21.38 percent in the previous year, the Commerce Ministry announced earlier on Wednesday. Imports in 1996/97 rose to $38.55 billion from $36.37 billion in the previous year.
The gaping trade deficit widened to $5.44 billion from $4.54 billion in the previous year, the ministry said.
